Au@Snβ zeolite as stable and active catalyst for the conversion of glycerol to methyl lactate Shengqiang Zhou Data curation a Tianliang Lu Validation Supervision b Lipeng Zhou Writing – review & editing Supervision a ⁎ Xiaomei Yang Validation Methodology a ⁎ a College of Chemistry, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, China College of Chemistry Zhengzhou University Zhengzhou 450001 China College of Chemistry, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, China b School of Chemical Engineering, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, China School of Chemical Engineering Zhengzhou University Zhengzhou 450001 China School of Chemical Engineering, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Au/Sn-zeolite catalysts showed high activity for selective conversion of glycerol to methyl lactate, but suffered from poor stability under the reaction conditions in our previous report (ACS Catal. 2017, 7, 7274). Encapsulation of Au nanoparticles within zeolite is a promising strategy to enhance their stability in catalytic reaction. Herein, one-pot synthesis of Au@Snβ was achieved by a mercaptosilane-assisted hydrothermal synthesis method. The protocol involves crystallization of Snβ synthesis gels around coordinated Au precursors, resulting in Snβ framework constraining Au coordination complexes. The confinement of small (∼2.89 nm) and uniform Au particles within Snβ was achieved. The bifunctional catalyst composed of oxidative sites (Au) and Lewis acid sites (Sn) gave 77.3 % methyl lactate (MLA) yield from the base-free selective conversion of glycerol (GLY). The TOF value of Au@Snβ was higher than that of Au/Sn-zeolite in our previous report. Moreover, the special structure protects Au nanoparticles from sintering or agglomeration and improves the stability and recyclability in selective oxidation of GLY to MLA. Keywords Au@Snβ Glycerol Oxidation Methyl lactate Stability Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Multifunctional catalysts containing two or more types of active sites are promising catalysts for coupling multiple reactions in one-pot to produce desired chemicals, eliminating the costly and time-consuming process for separating or purifying intermediates. Metal-acid composites with dual active sites are commonly employed to catalyze tandem reactions because each type of site can catalyze a specific step of the reaction. Zeolites as prominent solid acid materials, by virtue of their hydrothermal stability and high surface area and porosity, are particularly suitable for assembling such bifunctional catalysts, e.g. by incorporating redox-active metal sites. Indeed, noble metals (Pt, Pd) supported on zeolites (MFI [1], *BEA [2], *MRE [3], FAU [4], etc.) have been widely developed for hydroisomerization of linear alkanes to high-value branched isomers. Currently, bifunctional metal-zeolite catalysts are also extensively studied for upgrading renewable raw materials such as biomass and related platform chemicals. For example, the selective oxidation of glycerol (GLY) to lactic acid and its esters over Pt/Sn-MFI [5] and Au/Sn-USY [6], the conversion of levulinic acid to γ-valerolactone over Ru/H-ZSM-5 [7] or to pentanoic acid over Pt/H-ZSM-5 [8]. The composite catalyst is usually assembled by direct impregnation method. However, impregnated active components are prone to redistributing and agglomerating into larger particles in the catalytic reactions due to the weak interaction with zeolite, resulting in partial loss of activity. To alleviate these issues, researchers have strengthened metal-zeolite interactions by introducing a second metal to enhance the dispersion and stability of the metal phase. For example, Pt nanoclusters were successfully immobilized in Zn- or Sn-containing zeolite (Zn-MFI, Snβ) by anchoring effect afforded by framework-heteroatom [9,10]. Karthikeyan et al. demonstrated that the introduction of Ni component could enhance the reduction and dispersion of Pd, and the isomer selectivity on Pd-Ni/Y was significantly improved compared with that on single-component Pd/Y and Ni/Y catalysts during the isomerization of n-octane [11]. Recently, Xiao et al. proposed a seed-directed route to synthesize M@Zeolite (Pt@Beta, Pt@MOR, Rh@Beta, Rh@MOR, Ag@Beta, Ag@MOR, Pt@Beta-Fe and Pd@S-1) [12]. In this method, metal-nanoparticle-containing zeolite seeds induced the epitaxial growth of zeolite in aluminosilicate gels via a core–shell growth process, fixing metal nanoparticles within the newly formed zeolite framework. In addition, direct hydrothermal synthesis of metal@zeolites with ligand-assisted metal precursors is one of the most commonly employed strategies. In these cases, organic additives, such as cationic polymers [13,14] or sulfur- [15–17] or nitrogen-containing [18–20] compounds, are necessary for stabilizing metal species during zeolite crystallization. Recently, zeolite-confined metal catalysts have also been applied to many catalytic fields, such as hydrogen production [18], alkanes oxidation [19,21], propane dehydrogenation [22,23], upgrading biomass-based derivatives [24,25], and removal of volatile organic compounds [26]. Gold catalysts have been used in several important reactions (low-temperature CO oxidation [27], acetylene hydrochlorination [28], water–gas shift reaction [29], and alcohol oxidation [30]) since Haruta and Hutchings found that gold nanoparticles with the size below 5 nm were highly active. However, small metal particles generally have poor thermal stability and are prone to sintering and aggregation in harsh reaction environments. Given the facile reduction [31] and low Tamman temperature of gold species compared to other noble metals, stabilizing gold nanoparticles are quite difficult. It is difficult to construct stable and highly dispersed supported gold nanoparticles compared with platinum group metals (Pt, Rh and Ru) [10,32,33]. As mentioned above, encapsulation of metal nanoparticles in zeolite provides opportunities to restrain their growth. Ion-exchange method is an effective way to obtain highly dispersed metal clusters within zeolite channels, but until now only cage-type Y zeolites were reported to confine highly dispersed gold nanoparticles (∼1 nm) [34,35]. Solvent-free synthesis was carried out to encapsulate gold nanoparticles in S-1 zeolite [36]. In-situ crystallization was conducted using amorphous SiO2-coated metal nanoparticles (Au and Pd) as raw materials. However, the size distribution of monometallic Au nanoparticles (3–9 nm) within S-1 zeolite was wide and significantly larger than that of bimetallic Au-Pd alloy nanoparticles (2.5–6.5 nm) [36–38]. Iglesia et al. has made remarkable contributions to the preparation of metal nanoparticles encapsulated in microporous zeolite via ligand-protected route. (3-Mercaptopropyl)trimethoxysilane (MPTS) was applied to stabilize gold precursors and prevent their precipitation, resulting in the successful encapsulation of Au nanoparticles in aluminosilicate zeolites (LTA and MFI). However, the synthesis of high silica or pure silica zeolites is usually performed at elevated temperatures, which is extremely challenging for the stability of ligand-protected metal precursors. For example, the crystallization temperature of TS-1 changed from 175 °C to 120 °C, the size distribution of gold nanoparticles decreased from 5-50 nm to 2.8–3.8 nm [15]. In addition, alkalinity is also crucial for the successful confinement of noble metal nanoparticles; too high or too low alkalinity lead to inefficient encapsulation [39,40]. Highly-dispersed Au nanoparticles deposited on Sn-containing zeolite were quite effective for the one-pot conversion of GLY to methyl lactate (MLA) [6], acetol to lactic acid [41], and oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural [42]. Among the processes, the catalytic conversion of GLY to lactic acid and its derivatives is a promising reaction because the resulting products have extensive applications in food, pharmaceutical, green solvent and renewable polylactic acid fields. The tandem reaction of GLY to lactic acid or MLA driven by both metal sites and Lewis acid sites includes (1) oxidation of GLY to triose such as 1,3-dihydroxyacetone (DHA) and glyceraldehyde (GA) on Au sites, (2) isomerization of triose to lactic acid or MLA on Sn sites. For the base-free transformation of GLY to MLA, Au/USY prepared by deposition of Au nanoparticles on USY zeolite gave 73 % yield of MLA at 160 °C for 10 h [43]. Inspired by this work, the multifunctional catalysts were developed by physically mixing Au/CuO or AuPd/CNTs (CNTs, carbon nanotubes) with mesoporous Sn-MCM-41 zeolite [44,45]. Recently, our research revealed the promotion effect of Sn in Au/Sn-USY on the dispersion of Au particles, hence improving the yield of MLA (79 %) [6]. Meanwhile, Au/CuO synthesized by deposition–precipitation method was used as a co-catalyst of Snβ zeolite to catalyze the conversion of GLY at a low reaction temperature (90 °C) [46]. However, most of supported Au catalysts suffer from the relatively poor hydrothermal stability and unsatisfactory recyclability. Supported Au/Sn catalysts were easy to lose activity after limited number of recycling tests, and large Au particles were formed after reaction. In our previous report [6], Au/Sn-USY was prepared by a modified colloidal deposition method. Fresh Au/Sn-USY showed good catalytic activity for the conversion of GLY to MLA. However, the catalytic activity of Au/Sn-USY decreased obviously in the third recycling run. The increase of the particle size of Au was observed due to the low Tamman temperature of Au, resulting in severe loss of activity. In our following study [46], Au was supported on CuO to stabilize Au nanoparticles. Au/CuO and Snβ binary catalyst showed good catalytic activity for the conversion of GLY to MLA in mild conditions as compared with Au/Sn-USY. The recycling stability of the catalyst is superior than Au/Sn-USY due to the low reaction temperature. However, the obvious growth of Au particles is observed. Therefore, it can be seen that poor hydrothermal stability of Au/Sn-zeolites is mainly due to the relatively weak metal-support interaction for silica-based zeolite supports, as well as the absence of a spatial barrier to prevent the migration of gold species and agglomeration of gold particles in reaction conditions. Confining Au nanoparticles in mesoporous silica shell coated on Snβ zeolite [47] and preparing Au-Pd bimetallic alloy catalysts [45] can also improve the catalytic activity and stability to some extent in GLY conversion. Snβ zeolite has been extensively studied and shown superior catalytic performance in the isomerization of trioses. Encapsulation of ultrasmall Au nanoparticles within Snβ zeolite is expected to be an ideal bifunctional catalyst for effective conversion of GLY to MLA with good stability. In this paper, Au nanoparticles encapsulated in Snβ zeolite were directly synthesized by the hydrothermal method with the assistance of mercaptosilane. Mercaptosilane as a stabilizer of Au precursor prevents formation of bulk Au particles during the aging and crystallization process. The bifunctional catalyst of Au@Snβ with both oxidation sites (Au) and Lewis acid sites (Sn) was tested in conversion of GLY to MLA, which exhibited excellent catalytic performance and stability. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Tetraethylammonium hydroxide (TEAOH, 25 wt% aqueous solution), tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, AR), MPTS (98 %), methyl glycerate (MGLA, 97 %) and methyl glycolate (MGO, 98 %) were obtained from Aladdin Industrial Corporation. Methyl pyruvate (MPA, 98 %) was obtained from Alfa Aesar. HAuCl4·4H2O was obtained from Tianjin Fuchen Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Tin chloride pentahydrate (SnCl4·5H2O, AR) and pyridine were obtained from Tianjin Kermel Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Hydrofluoric acid (HF, 40 wt%) was obtained from Tianjin Fuyu Fine Chemical Co., Ltd. Anhydrous methanol and GLY were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. MLA (98 %) was obtained from TCI Shanghai, China. Naphthalene was purchased from Xinxiang Chemical Reagent Factory. 2.2 Synthesis Au@Snβ samples were prepared via a modified route for Snβ synthesis [48] by introducing Au species into Snβ synthesis gels together with MPTS [16]. Briefly, MPTS was mixed with TEAOH solution and stirred for 8 h. A certain volume of HAuCl4 (25 mM) solution was added dropwise under stirring until homogenization, followed by addition of TEOS. After 90 min, aqueous solution of SnCl4·5H2O was slowly added. The mixture was stirred continuously and heated to evaporate the ethanol from hydrolysis of TEOS and excess water. HF solution was added to the above mixture, and then Siβ seeds (4 wt%) dispersed in water were added and mixed homogeneously. The molar ratio of the resulting gel was 0.005 SnO2: 1.0 SiO2: 0.54 TEAOH: 0.54 HF: 7.5 H2O: 0.003 Au: 0.027 MPTS. Subsequently, the gel was heated statically at 140 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure. The as-made solid was washed with deionized water and separated by filtration. After drying overnight at 100 °C, the powder was calcined at 550 °C for 8 h in air. The obtained sample was denoted as xAu(m)@ySnβtd, where x and y represent the theoretical mass percent of Au and Sn in the powder; m and t represent n MPTS/n Au and crystallization time, respectively. The crystallization time for samples with varying Sn content (0, 0.5 %, 1 % and 2 %) was 1, 2, 3 and 15 days, respectively [49]. The reference sample 1Au/1Snβ3d was prepared by supporting Au nanoparticles on 1Snβ3d according to our previous report [6]. 2.3 Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected by a Panalytical X’pert PRO instrument in the range 2θ = 5-50° using Cu Kα radiation. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were obtained using a Zeiss-sigma 500 instrument. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained using a Tecnai G2 F20 S-Twin electron microscope operated at 200 kV. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) elemental mapping was conducted in scanning TEM (STEM) mode. Before measurements, the samples were dispersed in ethanol by ultrasonication and then dripped onto a carbon-coated copper grid. Ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) spectra were acquired using a Shimadzu UV-26001 spectrophotometer. Diffuse reflectance ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis DR) spectra were taken to detect plasmon resonance bands of Au nanoparticles in Au@Snβ with an Agilent Technologies Cary Series UV–vis-NIR spectrophotometer. Au and Sn contents were measured through induced coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) using an iCAP 6000 SERIES instrument. N2 sorption isotherms were obtained using a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 instrument. The samples were degassed at 300 °C for 3 h before measurement. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy of pyridine adsorption (pyridine-FTIR) was conducted using a Bruker Tenser II FT-IR spectrometer. The self-supporting wafer was sealed and preheated at 450 °C for 1 h under vacuum. After the cell was cooled to room temperature, the spectra of the hydroxyl region were recorded and used as the background for the following pyridine adsorption and desorption test. Pyridine vapor was introduced into the quartz cell until adsorption saturation. The pyridine-FTIR spectrum was obtained by heating the wafer to the target temperature for 0.5 h and cooling again to room temperature. Chemical states of Au and Sn were analysed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) on a RBD upgraded PHI-5000C ESCA system (PerkinElmer) at 250 W and 14.0 kV (Mg Kα radiation, hν = 1253.6 eV). The binding energy values were calibrated using C 1 s peak at 284.6 eV. 2.4 Catalytic test Catalytic conversion of GLY to MLA was performed in a batch reactor. Typically, GLY (1 mmol) and Au@Snβ (100 mg) were mixed with methanol (5 mL) in the reactor. Then, the reactor was sealed and flushed four times with O2 to replace air and finally pressurized to 0.5 MPa with O2. The reactor was heated to a designated temperature at a heating rate of 3.5 °C min−1 and held for a desired time. After reaction, the reactor was quenched in ice water. The separation of catalyst and liquid was carried out by centrifugation. The collected liquid was quantitatively analyzed by internal standard method (naphthalene) using a Shimadzu GC-2014C with an FID detector. The conversion of GLY and the yields of products (MLA, MGLA, MPA and MGO) were calculated according to the GC results using the following equations (1) and (2): (1) GLY c o n v e r s i o n = moles o f G L Y r e a c t e d moles o f s t a r t i n g G L Y × 100 % (2) MLA y i e l d = moles o f M L A p r o d u c e d moles o f s t a r t i n g G L Y × 100 % TOF is calculated using the equation (3) based on moles of MLA formed per hour per mole of exposed surface Au atoms: (3) TOF ( h - 1 ) = ( m o l e s o f M L A p r o d u c e d ) ( m o l e s o f A u i n t h e c a t a l y s t ) × ( d i s p e r s i o n o f A u ) × ( r e a c t i o n t i m e ) where dispersion of Au (D) was defined as the fraction of exposed surface Au atoms; and D was estimated using the equation (4) in literature [16,50]: (4) D = 6 × ( ν m / a m ) d where ν m and a m represent bulk atomic density of Au (16.94 × 10-3 nm3) and the surface area occupied by an atom on a polycrystalline surface of Au (8.75 × 10-2 nm2), respectively; d (nm) represents the average size of Au particle measured by TEM. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis of Au@Snβ X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of Au@Snβ with different Au, Sn content and n MPTS/n Au are shown in Fig. 1 . All samples showed sharp diffraction peaks at 2θ of 7.7° and 22.4°, which are typical topological structure of *BEA [51]. When the Au content in the precursor gel is less than 1 % while the Sn content is fixed at 1 %, no diffraction peaks assigned to gold phase appears, indicating that the gold species are well dispersed in the zeolite (Fig. 1a). Sn content has a significant impact on the crystallization of β zeolite [49]. A series of samples were synthesized by controlling the gold content at 1 % while varying the Sn content to 0, 0.5 %, 1 % and 2 %. For these Sn-containing samples, no diffraction peaks ascribed to SnO2 are observed, suggesting that Sn species are highly dispersed. However, when Sn content was 2 %, two diffraction peaks ascribed to Au(111) and Au(200) appeared at 2θ of 38.1° and 44.3°, respectively, indicating the presence of large Au nanoparticles in 1Au(6)@2Snβ15d. The extended crystallization time of 15 days to obtain fully crystallized 1Au(6)@2Snβ15d with high Sn content would result in the partial decomposition of MPTS and weaken the stabilization effect on Au species. Additionally, the reaction between Sn precursor and MPTS could also consume some MPTS. As a consequence, only a limited amount of MPTS was available to act as the stabilizer for gold precursor, leading to the formation of large gold nanoparticles. The n MPTS/n Au is very important for the synthesis of Au@Snβ zeolite with uniform Au nanoparticles. If no MPTS was added to the gel mixture during the aging process, the Au precursor rapidly precipitated from the solution as black insoluble substance under strong alkaline conditions. The mercapto group (−SH) in MPTS interacts strongly with Au3+ to generate stable Au-S adducts, while the alkoxysilane moiety hydrolyzes to generate siloxane bridges with the silica precursors. This multifunctional structure enables MPTS to stabilize gold species and achieve encapsulation of gold species in the following crystallization process. XRD patterns of Au@Snβ zeolites with different n MPTS/n Au are shown in Fig. 1c. No diffraction peaks of SnO2 or gold appear. When high n MPTS/n Au was used, the diffraction peak intensity of the samples decreased slightly. The long alkyl chains in MPTS probably interfered with the organization of the stannosilicates [52]. SEM images (Fig. S1-S3) exhibit the characteristic morphology of capped square bipyramidal (CSBP); the crystal height decreased with increasing tin content, which is consistent with the previous reports [49,53]. The introduction of gold into Snβ zeolite had no significant effect on the crystal morphology. However, with the increase of n MPTS/n Au, a small number of amorphous phases were observed, which agrees with the results of XRD. The Sn contents are close to the theoretical values (Table S1), while the Au contents are slightly lower than those introduced in the synthesis gel. The porosity of Au-containing zeolites was measured by N2 physisorption (Fig. S4, Table S2). N2 isotherms in type I show high nitrogen adsorption capacity at low relative pressure and the adsorption capacity slowly increased at high relative pressure, which are the characteristics of microporous materials. These results confirm that the introduction of gold species in β zeolite did not change the zeolite framework. 3.2 Size of Au nanoparticles Fig. 2 shows the TEM and corresponding EDX elemental mapping of relevant samples. Au nanoparticles in 1Au(6)@1Snβ3d (Fig. 2b) are better dispersed and the size is smaller than those in 0.5Au(6)@1Snβ3d (Fig. 2a). Other samples with different Au contents are shown in Fig. S5. It seems unreasonable that small Au nanoparticle size is presented at high Au content in the sample, and the possible reasons are as follows. On the one hand, MPTS decomposed under harsh synthesis conditions and its multifunctional structure was destroyed. On the other hand, more MPTS coordinated with Au species in the gel at high Au content because more MPTS were added to the gel. As a result, Au nanoparticles in 1Au(6)@1Snβ3d dispersed better and are smaller than those in 0.5Au(6)@1Snβ3d. The size evolution of Au nanoparticles was also monitored by UV–vis DR spectroscopy (Fig. S6) owing to strong local surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) around 520 nm [54–57]. The peak shifted in the order of 0.25Au(6)@1Snβ3d (538 nm) > 0.5Au(6)@1Snβ3d (530 nm) ≈ 0.75Au(6)@1Snβ3d (530 nm) > 1Au(6)@1Snβ3d (519 nm). The blue shift can be attributed to the reduced size of gold nanoparticles, which is consistent with the above TEM analysis. Then, the changes of gold nanoparticles in Au@Snβ with different Sn content are analyzed. In the case of 1Au(6)@Siβ1d (Fig. 2c), it is clear that some Au nanoparticles were distributed at the outer edge of the crystal, and the Au nanoparticle size was slightly larger than that of 1Au(6)@1Snβ3d. After the introduction of 1 % Sn (Fig. 2b), the dispersion of gold nanoparticles was promoted and almost all of them were uniformly distributed inside the zeolite crystals. As for 1Au(6)@2Snβ15d (Fig. 2d) with high Sn content, it was difficult to observe the presence of gold species in the TEM mode, while large bright spots assigned to agglomerated Au were observed by STEM in the inset of Fig. 2d. This is in accordance with the XRD results in Fig. 1. 1Au(9)@1Snβ3d prepared by further increasing n MPTS/n Au to 9, presents the uniform dispersion of Au nanoparticles throughout the β crystal with an average particle size of 2.89 nm (Fig. 2e). The corresponding STEM and EDX elemental mapping images of 1Au(9)@1Snβ3d (Fig. 2g) show that Au and Sn elements are uniformly distributed in the zeolite crystal and no obvious agglomeration occurs. Furthermore, the thermal stability of 1Au(9)@1Snβ3d was tested by raising the calcination temperature to 600 °C (1Au(9)@1Snβ3d-600, Fig. 2f). Au nanoparticles did not agglomerate and the size only slightly increased, verifying the high thermal stability of Au particles confined in 1Au(9)@1Snβ3d. Tomogram-section TEM was carried out to observe the location of Au nanoparticles (Fig. 2h, 2i and S7). Au nanoparticles are clearly observed from cross section, suggesting that these particles are indeed confined within Snβ crystals. 3.3 Acid properties Pyridine-FTIR spectroscopy was used to characterize the acidity of the samples (Fig. 3 ). The peaks at 1452 cm−1, 1491 cm−1 and 1611 cm−1 are attributed to pyridine bound to Lewis acid sites [58]. For all these samples, no characteristic absorption peak at 1546 cm−1 ascribing to Brønsted acid site was observed, indicating that only Lewis acid sites were present. The amount of Lewis acid sites (Table 1 ) was calculated from pyridine-FTIR spectra according to the equation given in the literature [58]. No signal appeared for 1Au(6)@Siβ1d without Sn and the amount of Lewis acid sites was negligible, indicating that the presence of Au alone did not contribute to the Lewis acid sites. After the introduction of tin, all samples showed Lewis acidity. Moreover, the Lewis acid amount of xAu(m)@1Snβ3d was higher than that of 1Snβ3d. This may be due to the addition of MPTS in the gel, which not only played a role in stabilizing the Au precursor, but also protected the Sn species from aggregation and precipitation prior to incorporation into the framework of β zeolite. The result was confirmed by UV–vis spectroscopy (Fig. S8). In the mixture of SnCl4 and MPTS, characteristic bands of SnCl4 (206 nm) and MPTS (206 nm and 226 nm) were observed, while a new band appeared at around 284 nm. The red shift of signals in UV–vis spectrum was considered as a higher coordination number of Sn center [59]. Therefore, the peak at 284 nm can be attributed to increased coordination number caused by the coordination of MPTS with Sn center. 3.4 Chemical state XPS results are shown in Fig. 4 . In general, SnO2 shows Sn 3d signals at 495.0 eV and 486.6 eV corresponding to 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 of octahedral Sn species [60]. For 1Snβ3d, higher binding energy values of 496.4 eV and 488.1 eV attributing to tetrahedrally coordinated framework Sn species are observed [60,61]. After the introduction of Au species, the Sn 3d signals of 1Au(9)@1Snβ3d shifted slightly towards lower binding energy (496.2 eV and 487.8 eV) compared to 1Snβ3d, but were still much higher than those of SnO2. These results reveal that Sn species are incorporated into the zeolite framework sites and the existence of Au-Sn interaction. In the Au 4f region (Fig. 4b), the binding energy at 87.8 eV and 84.1 eV are observed for Au(6)@Siβ1d, which are related to Au 4f5/2 and Au 4f7/2 of typical Au0 [46]. In contrast, Au 4f peaks in 1Au(6)@1Snβ3d slightly shifted to higher binding energy of 87.9 eV and 84.2 eV, and further shifted to 88.1 eV and 84.4 eV in 1Au(9)@1Snβ3d due to the Au-Sn interaction, speculating electrons transfer from Au to Sn and formation of Au species with minor positive charge [42]. Moreover, the enhanced interaction between Au and Sn promoted the dispersion and confinement of Au nanoparticles in Snβ zeolite. According to the XPS results, the structural mode for Au confined in Snβ zeolite was also analyzed. Metallic Au was formed when as-made sample was calcined in air to decompose the Au precursors; meanwhile, the state of Sn(IV) for framework Sn species in Au@Snβ was proved. The interaction between Au nanoparticle and Sn(IV) is more likely to interact via Au-O-Sn bond. Similar results were reported in Pt@Snβ [10]. 3.5 Catalytic performance Selective catalytic conversion of GLY to MLA was carried out over the catalysts with different synthesis parameters including Au content, Sn content and n MPTS/n Au (Table 2 ). Two control experiments were first performed without catalyst or with 1Snβ3d alone. Almost no GLY was converted, indicating that GLY is quite stable in the catalytic system without oxidation active sites. After introducing gold species into Snβ zeolite, the oxidation reaction of GLY took place. For 0.25Au(6)@1Snβ3d, 14.3 % GLY was converted. When the Au content increased from 0.25 % to 0.75 %, GLY conversion gradually increased from 14.3 % to 42.0 %. Further increasing Au content to 1 %, GLY conversion increased sharply to 83.8 %. These results suggest that gold nanoparticles were the catalytic oxidation sites for GLY, which is associated with the size and dispersion of Au besides the Au content. This is consistent with the previous TEM results that small and highly dispersed gold nanoparticles were produced by increasing Au content to a certain extent, resulting in enhanced catalytic activity. Accordingly, MLA yield increased from 10.0 % to 56.9 % with the increase of Au content from 0.25 % to 1 %. In addition to MLA, several oxidation by-products including MGLA, MPA and MGO were detected. Their yields increased with the enhanced oxidation activity brought by elevating Au content. Turnover frequency (TOF) values of Au@Snβ with different Au contents for MLA formation were calculated and given in Table S3. The TOF values of the related catalysts increase in the order of 0.25Au(6)@1Snβ3d < 0.5Au(6)@1Snβ3d < 0.75Au(6)@1Snβ3d < 1Au(6)@1Snβ3d, which is in accordance with the order of MLA yield at 1.5 h. 1Au(6)@1Snβ3d with higher Au content gives higher activity for MLA formation than 0.25Au(6)@1Snβ3d. The increase of TOF value and MLA yield with Au content is correlated well with the reduction of Au nanoparticle size (from 4.39 nm down to 3.07 nm). The trend of TOF is related to Au particle size shown in Fig. S9. Smaller Au nanoparticles show higher activity, resulting in higher TOF. The TOF value of Au@Snβ (772 h−1) is higher than that of Au/Sn-USY (505 h−1, calculated by the equation in this work) in our previous report [6], which is due to the smaller particle size of Au. To study the role of Lewis acid Sn sites, the catalytic performance of the prepared catalysts with different Sn contents was tested. 1Au(6)@Siβ was designed as a control catalyst and gave 73.1 % GLY conversion and limited MLA yield (3.4 %), while MGLA was formed by over-oxidation with 21.7 % yield. When Sn was introduced, the product distribution changed significantly. For example, for 1Au(6)@0.5Snβ2d, GLY conversion changed slightly, but the MLA yield increased sharply to 45.0 %. Moreover, the MLA yield increased from 45.0 % to 56.9 % and the MLA selectivity varied from 59.9 % to 67.9 % with the increase of Sn content from 0.5 % to 1 %, because the increased Sn sites promoted the conversion of intermediates to MLA. DHA is an intermediate in catalytic conversion of GLY to MLA. The effect of Lewis acidity on DHA conversion and MLA formation was investigated using Snβ alone. As shown in Fig. S10, both linear dependence of DHA conversion and MLA yield on the Lewis acid amount were observed. It is concluded that Lewis acid sites of the framework Sn are the active sites for further converting the intermediate products from GLY oxidation to MLA. It is worth noting that GLY conversion also increased from 75.1 % to 83.8 %, although the Au content was identical, meaning that the presence of Sn promoted the oxidation activity of Au. The oxidation activity was originated from gold nanoparticles in the Au-Sn bifunctional catalysts. Smaller and highly dispersed gold nanoparticles were formed after Sn species were introduced according to TEM results. The promoted oxidation activity of Au was mainly due to that tin element promoted the dispersion of gold, resulting in the formation of highly dispersed gold nanoparticles. On the other hand, strong Lewis acidity is helpful for the conversion of the intermediates from GLY oxidation to the target product timely. So, the formation of corresponding carboxylic acids (e.g. glyceric acid) was reduced, which are considered as possible inhibitors of the active oxidation sites [45]. Unexpectedly, when the Sn content was further increased to 2 %, the catalytic activity decreased sharply due to that poor Au dispersion was produced at excessive Sn content, as seen from the TEM image of 1Au(6)@2Snβ15d. The primary function of MPTS is to stabilize gold species, so the effect of n MPTS/n Au on the catalytic performance was studied. In the absence of MPTS, only 4.8 % of GLY conversion was obtained. The introduction of MPTS facilitated the dispersion of Au, thereby enhancing its catalytic activity. When n MPTS/n Au was 9, the prepared 1Au(9)@1Snβ3d gave the highest GLY conversion and MLA yield of 93.8 % and 68.6 %, respectively. Subsequently, the effects of the reaction temperature and time on the catalytic performance of 1Au(9)@1Snβ3d were investigated. As shown in Fig. 5 , 88.0 % GLY conversion was obtained at 140 °C, while ∼ 100 % GLY conversion was reached at 160 °C or 180 °C. MLA yield increased first from 64.4 % to 72.0 % with an elevation in temperature from 140 °C to 160 °C and then decreased to 54.5 % at 180 °C. Meanwhile, the over-oxidation by-products of MPA and MGO were formed by further conversion of MLA and MGLA [47]. Moreover, the recovered solution was colorless and transparent except that at 180 °C. Thus, the drop of MLA yield at higher reaction temperature was caused by over-oxidation or polymerization. A time course of GLY and products over 1Au(9)@1Snβ3d was performed at 160 °C to provide further insight into the reaction pathway (Fig. 6 ). The catalyst was highly active and 52.5 % GLY conversion was achieved within 0.5 h. The GLY conversion reached 100 % after 2.5 h and at this time the MLA yield reached its maximum of 77.3 %. The by-products of MGLA, MPA and MGO increased slightly from 7.0 %, 3.8 % and 1.5 % to 9.6 %, 6.2 % and 3.1 %, respectively. Subsequently, the reaction pathway from GLY to MLA was concluded based on the reaction results using different substrates (GLY, DHA, MLA and MGLA) in Table S4. When GLY was used as a substrate over 1Au(6)@Siβ1d, 1Au(9)@1Snβ3d and 1Snβ3d (Table S4, entries 1–3), GLY was converted on the former two samples and almost no conversion was observed in the latter sample, indicating that Au was responsible for GLY oxidation. MLA was formed only on Au(9)@1Snβ3d, implying different reaction routes on the above Au catalysts. Meanwhile, the presence of Sn may catalyze the further conversion of intermediate. DHA is commonly regarded as the intermediate in catalytic oxidation of GLY. When DHA was used a substrate (Table S4, entry 4), MLA was easily produced over 1Snβ3d. Taken together, MLA was formed by tandem route of GLY → DHA → MLA. Furthermore, the over-oxidation of MLA and MGLA was investigated. When MLA was used as a substrate (Table S4, entry 5), small amount of MPA was formed, indicating that MPA could be formed by over-oxidation of MLA. As for the route of by-products formed, especially conversion of MGLA, the reaction was carried out with MGLA as a substrate (Table S4, entry 6), and small amount of MGO was produced. The possible reaction pathway for producing MLA and by-products was depicted in Fig. 7 , which includes oxidation of GLY to DHA or GA intermediates on Au sites, followed by acid-catalyzed dehydration and isomerization of intermediates to MLA, or their further oxidation to MPA, MGLA and MGO on Au sites. Such reaction pathway provides guidance to optimize the catalyst activity by finely tuning Au and Sn content. The structure characteristic of Au@Snβ is that Au nanoparticles were confined in Snβ crystals as compared with our previous work. Au sites provide the catalytic oxidation sites for the conversion of GLY to DHA/GA intermediates. The subsequent conversion of DHA/GA to MLA was catalyzed by Lewis acid site of Snβ. To gain further insight into the interaction between Sn and Au, especially the effect of introduction of Au on Lewis acid Sn sites, we decoupled the multistep tandem reaction and investigated each step that Sn sites functioned. As shown in Table 3 , the reaction of DHA over Sn-containing catalysts showed that this intermediate was readily converted to MLA. In these samples, high catalytic activity was achieved for 1Snβ3d (Table 3, entry 4). After Au species were introduced, the catalytic activity of Au-Sn catalysts decreased to some extent. In the case of supporting Au nanoparticles onto 1Snβ3d (1Au/1Snβ3d), a notable decrease in catalytic activity was observed for the conversion of DHA to MLA. In contrast, the decrease in catalytic activity was less pronounced for 1Au(6)@1Snβ3d with confined Au species. It indicates that Au loading partially blocked the Lewis acid Sn sites, whereas the blocking was reduced when Au was located inside the crystals. This highlights the importance of the encapsulation of Au in Snβ zeolite. When GLY was used as a reactant, 1Au(6)@1Snβ3d exhibited almost 2-fold high MLA yield in comparison to 0.75Au(6)@1Snβ3d (Table 2, entries 5 and 6), but their performance for DHA conversion were comparable. This indicates that converting GLY to MLA is not determined by the isomerization of DHA, but by the oxidation of GLY to DHA, which was considered to be the rate-determining step of GLY conversion to MLA [62–64]. Meanwhile, 67.9 % of MLA selectivity was obtained from conversion of GLY over 1Au(6)@1Snβ3d (Table 2, entry 6), which is higher than that from DHA (56.3 %). This implies a positive effect of Au-Sn interaction on Sn active centers. The stability of noble-metal catalyst is an important issue due to irreversible sintering or aggregation of metal particles in catalytic reaction. Therefore, the recyclability of Au@Snβ catalyst was investigated and compared with that of 1Au/1Snβ3d catalyst. The catalyst recovered after each run was thoroughly washed with methanol and used directly for the next run. As shown in Fig. 8 a, the reused 1Au(9)@1Snβ3d catalyst gave 95.8 % GLY conversion and 63.6 % MLA yield at the 6th run, which was comparable to the fresh catalyst. However, 1Au/1Snβ3d suffers from gradual deactivation through six consecutive runs (Fig. 8b), with a significant reduction in the GLY conversion from 88.3 % to 52.7 % and the MLA yield from 63.5 % to 36.6 %. It is clear that the confined 1Au(9)@1Snβ3d catalyst shows satisfactory catalytic performance and stability compared to supported 1Au/1Snβ3d catalyst, which well correlated with its special structure. Compared to supported 1Au/1Snβ3d catalyst (Fig. S11), small Au nanoparticles were observed in 1Au(9)@1Snβ3d, which were highly active for conversion of GLY. In addition, when Au was confined in the crystals, the Lewis acid sites were rarely blocked (Table 3), which facilitated the conversion of the intermediates to MLA. The confinement of Au nanoparticles in Snβ crystal provides physical hindrance for stability of gold during heat treatment and catalytic reaction. In order to reveal the reason for good stability of confined Au catalyst, the spent catalysts were collected and analyzed by XRD, ICP and TEM (Fig. 9 ). *BEA-type structure of the spent 1Au(9)@1Snβ3d was retained well, proving that the crystalline phase structure was stable. ICP results show that the Au and Sn contents in spent 1Au(9)@1Snβ3d (0.63 % and 0.76 %) are close to those of the fresh sample (0.65 % and 0.77 %), indicating that there is almost no loss of Au and Sn during the reaction. The result means that the confinement structure of Au@Snβ can effectively stabilize the Au nanoparticles showing good hydrothermal stability during reaction. According to TEM result, the size of gold nanoparticles in the spent 1Au(9)@1Snβ3d (2.79 nm) did not change significantly compared to the fresh catalyst (2.89 nm). However, an obvious increase in Au nanoparticle size from 4.27 nm to 9.68 nm (Fig. S11) was observed for the 1Au/1Snβ3d catalyst after six runs. The catalytic properties of Au catalysts are very sensitive to their size effect, so the change of particle size is an important criterion to evaluate the stability of catalysts. Therefore, it can be concluded that the quick deactivation of 1Au/1Snβ3d is due to the apparent aggregation of Au nanoparticles. The main reason for the hydrothermal stability of confined Au catalyst Au@Snβ is that the structurally stable zeolite acts as a spatial barrier around the gold nanoparticles, preventing them from migrating and agglomerating into large particles during the liquid phase reaction. The reusability of 1Au(9)@1Snβ3d and 1Au/1Snβ3d catalysts was also studied in the initial reaction stage at 140 °C for 0.5 h. As shown in Fig. S12a, no significant change in GLY conversion and MLA yield was observed for 1Au(9)@1Snβ3d. However, a continuous decline in GLY conversion and MLA yield in the recycling experiments over 1Au/1Snβ3d was found (Fig. S12b). According to reported recyclability tests on different catalysts for the conversion of GLY to MLA, there was a 10 % decrease in MLA yield for the binary catalyst of Au/CuO and Snβ at the 2nd use [46], while 13 % decrease for Au/Sn-USY at the 3rd use [6]. As for Au/Snβ@mesosilica [47] and binary catalyst of Au/CuO and Sn-MCM-41 [44], the catalytic performance kept stable for four and five cycles, respectively, but both required recalcination for regeneration. Compared with these results, 1Au(9)@1Snβ3d exhibited high recyclability for six cycles without additional treatment, demonstrating the improved catalytic stability in the present work. 4 Conclusions In summary, mercaptosilane-assisted strategy can be extended to confine Au nanoparticles in Snβ zeolite hydrothermally synthesized in fluoride media. Introduction of Sn species promotes the dispersion of Au particles throughout the β crystal, and endows the catalysts with Lewis acidity. Moreover, the Au-Sn interaction was proved to enhance the oxidation of glycerol by analyzing each step reaction. Both Au sites and Lewis acid Sn sites participated in the tandem conversion of GLY to MLA in the base-free methanol. 77.3 % MLA yield was achieved over Au@Snβ catalyst. Furthermore, the catalyst can be facilely recycled and remain stable in structure and activity through six consecutive runs. In contrast, an obvious and continuous deactivation took place over Au supported Snβ catalysts. This work provides an efficient way to fabricate heteroatom zeolite encapsulating noble metal for tandem reactions. CRediT authorship contribution statement Shengqiang Zhou: Data curation. coredata.dc:description: Au/Sn-zeolite catalysts showed high activity for selective conversion of glycerol to methyl lactate, but suffered from poor stability under the reaction conditions in our previous report (ACS Catal. 2017, 7, 7274). Encapsulation of Au nanoparticles within zeolite is a promising strategy to enhance their stability in catalytic reaction. Herein, one-pot synthesis of Au@Snβ was achieved by a mercaptosilane-assisted hydrothermal synthesis method. The protocol involves crystallization of Snβ synthesis gels around coordinated Au precursors, resulting in Snβ framework constraining Au coordination complexes. The confinement of small (∼2.89 nm) and uniform Au particles within Snβ was achieved. The bifunctional catalyst composed of oxidative sites (Au) and Lewis acid sites (Sn) gave 77.3 % methyl lactate (MLA) yield from the base-free selective conversion of glycerol (GLY). The TOF value of Au@Snβ was higher than that of Au/Sn-zeolite in our previous report. Moreover, the special structure protects Au nanoparticles from sintering or agglomeration and improves the stability and recyclability in selective oxidation of GLY to MLA.
